meanings.definition: To insert or introduce (something) between other things
meanings.sent1: She interpolates colorful beads between the plain ones in her bracelet.
meanings.sent2: The teacher interpolates interesting facts between the textbook paragraphs.
meanings.sent3: The chef decided to interpolate a surprise ingredient into the recipe.
meanings.sent4: His speech was so moving that it seemed to interpolate hope into the hearts of the audience.
meanings.sent5: The artist's brush strokes carefully interpolate light and shadow in the painting.

meanings.definition: To estimate values between two known values
meanings.sent1: The scientist interpolates the missing data points on the graph.
meanings.sent2: Using the trend line, you can easily interpolate the values for the missing days.
meanings.sent3: It's like trying to interpolate the missing puzzle pieces to complete the picture.
meanings.sent4: Her intuition seemed to interpolate the future outcomes based on the current data.
meanings.sent5: The GPS system can accurately interpolate your location even in remote areas.

meanings.definition: To alter or falsify (a text) by the insertion of new matter
meanings.sent1: The forger interpolates fake signatures into the historical documents.
meanings.sent2: It is unethical to interpolate false information into research papers.
meanings.sent3: The prankster thought it would be funny to interpolate a silly joke into the serious report.
meanings.sent4: The hacker managed to interpolate a virus into the computer system undetected.
meanings.sent5: The spy's mission was to interpolate misleading information into the enemy's database.
